questions.text: Identify the arrow marked cell in the given condition below?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Plasma cell is a mononuclear cell with eccentric nucleus and a perinuclear halo. Option A- mononuclear cell with abundant cytoplasm and pale nucleus Option B- mononuclear cell with scanty cytoplasm and dense nucleus Option D- bilobed nucleus with eosinophilic coarse granules

questions.text: Which of the following cells will increase in case of parasite infection?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A- Neutrophil- increased in bacterial infections Option B- Basophil- increased in myeloproliferative neoplasms Option D- Lymphocyte- increased in viral infections

questions.text: Vasodilation in acute inflammation is seen earliest in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological Basis of Disease, 9th edition and Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th edition Vasodilation first involves the arterioles and then leads to opening of new capillary beds in the area. The result is increased blood flow, which is the cause of heat and redness (erythema) at the site of inflammation

questions.text: Increased permeability in acute inflammation is due to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological Basis of Disease, 9th edition and Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th edition

choices.text: Vasodilatation → Stasis → Transient vasoconstriction → Increased permeability
Transient vasoconstriction → Increased permeability → Stasis → Vasodilatation
Transient vasoconstriction → Vasodilatation → Stasis → Increased permeability
Transient vasoconstriction → Vasodilatation → Increased permeability → Stasis

questions.text: Sequence of events in acute inflammation:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Vasodilation is quickly followed by increased permeability of the microvasculature, with the outpouring of protein­rich fluid into the extravascular tissues; this process is described in detail below. The loss of fluid and increased vessel diameter lead to slower blood flow, concentration of red cells in small vessels, and increased viscosity of the blood. These changes result in engorgement of small vessels with slowly moving red cells, a condition termed stasis, which is seen as vascular congestion and localized redness of the involved tissue. As stasis develops, blood leukocytes, principally neutrophils, accumulate along the vascular endothelium. At the same time endothelial cells are activated by mediators produced at sites of infection and tissue damage, and express increased levels of adhesion molecules. Leukocytes then adhere to the endothelium, and soon afterward they migrate through the vascular wall into the interstitial tissue Hence order of steps in inflammation are as follows- Vasodilation (earliest in arterioles) → Increased permeability→ Exudative fluid leaks out → Edema → Slower blood flow → Hemoconcentration and Increased viscosity → Stasis → Margination

questions.text: The following is not an adhesion molecule?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Spectrin Spectrin is not an adhesion molecule. It is a cytoskeletal protein that helps maintain the structure of the plasma membrane by anchoring it to the cytoskeleton Other options: Integrins are transmembrane receptors involved in cell adhesion to the extracellular matrix (ECM) and other cells Selectins are adhesion molecules that mediate the interaction between leukocytes and endothelial cells during inflammation Cadherins are calcium-dependent adhesion molecules important for cell-to-cell adhesion in tissues

choices.text: Capillary adherence or sequestration of parasitized RBCs
Selective hemolysis of affected RBCs in spleen
Cellular lysis due to hemozoin produced by the parasites Erythrocyte changes in Malaria

questions.text: The RBCs with schizonts of P. Falciparum are not visible on peripheral blood smear due to which of the following reason?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Capillary adherence or sequestration of parasitized RBCs In P. falciparum infections, late-stage infected erythrocytes (those containing schizonts) adhere to endothelial cells lining capillaries and venules This phenomenon is known as cytoadherence and occurs due to the expression of P. falciparum erythrocyte membrane protein 1 (PfEMP1), which binds to host receptors like ICAM-1, CD36, and others The sequestration prevents these cells from circulating in the peripheral blood, thus making them rarely seen on smears Clinical relevance: This sequestration is a hallmark of severe malaria and contributes to complications like cerebral malaria and microvascular obstruction

questions.text: Amino acid which is useful in Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) as to causes lysis of chromatin is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The process is thought to begin with NADPH oxidase activation of protein-arginine deiminase 4 (PAD4) via reactive-oxygen species (ROS) intermediaries. PAD4 is responsible for the citrullination of histones in the neutrophil, resulting in decondensation of chromatin.

choices.text: Produced by neutrophils in response to infectious pathogens and inflammatory mediators
Provide a high concentration of antimicrobial substances at sites of infection
Prevent the spread of the microbes by trapping them in the fibrils

questions.text: The following statements are true regarding neutrophil extracellular trap:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) are extracellular fibrillar networks that concentrate anti-microbial substances at sites of infection and prevent the spread of the microbes by trapping them in the fibrils. They are produced by neutrophils in response to infectious pathogens (mainly bacteria and fungi) and inflammatory mediators (e.g., chemokines, cytokines, and complement proteins). The extracellular traps consist of a viscous meshwork of nuclear chromatin that binds and concentrates granule proteins such as anti-microbial peptides and enzymes. NETs provide an additional mechanism of killing microbes that does not involve phagocytosis. In the process of NET formation, the nuclei of the neutrophils are lost, leading to the death of the cells, sometimes called NETosis, representing a distinctive form of cell death affecting neutrophils. NETs also have been detected in the blood during sepsis. The nuclear chromatin in the NETs, which includes histones and associated DNA, may be a source of nuclear antigens in systemic autoimmune diseases, particularly lupus, in which individuals react against their own DNA and nucleoproteins NET is also called Beneficial Suicide of Neutrophils !!

questions.text: All of the following vascular changes are observed in acute inflammation, except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Decreased hydrostatic pressure: This does not occur in acute inflammation. Instead, hydrostatic pressure in capillaries initially increases due to vasodilation, promoting fluid leakage into tissues Vasodilation: An early response mediated by histamine and nitric oxide, leading to increased blood flow (redness and warmth) Stasis of blood: Vasodilation and increased vascular permeability slow blood flow, causing stasis, and allowing leukocyte margination Increased vascular permeability: Endothelial cells retract under the influence of mediators like histamine, bradykinin, and leukotrienes, leading to leakage of plasma proteins and fluids

questions.text: Correct sequence in extravasation of leukocytes is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The correct sequence of leukocyte extravasation (migration from blood vessels to the site of inflammation) is 1. Margination: Leukocytes move toward the periphery of blood vessels due to stasis of blood flow 2. Rolling: Leukocytes transiently adhere to endothelial cells via weak interactions mediated by selectins (e.g., E-selectin, P-selectin) 3. Adhesion: Firm attachment of leukocytes to endothelial cells occurs through interaction between integrins (on leukocytes) and ICAM-1 or VCAM-1 4. Diapedesis (Transmigration): Leukocytes squeeze through endothelial gaps into the extravascular space, mediated by PECAM-1 (CD31) 5. Chemotaxis: Leukocytes migrate toward the site of injury or infection, guided by chemical signals like cytokines, complement (C5a), and bacterial products

questions.text: Transmigration of WBC across the endothelium is called:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A and C- arrangement of leucocytes towards the margins of the vessel following increased permeability and loss of fluid Option B- unstable tethering of the leucocyte over the endothelial surface

questions.text: Which of the following is an alpha chemokine?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) IL-8 Chemokines are a family of small signalling proteins (about 8-10 kDa) that regulate the movement and activation of immune cells. They play a crucial role in the immune response by guiding immune cells to sites of infection, injury, or inflammation. They are classified into 4 major groups CXC Chemokines (Alpha Chemokines): • Structure: Two cysteine residues separated by one amino acid • Function: Primarily attract neutrophils and T-cells • Example: IL-1, IL-8, TNF CC Chemokines (Beta Chemokines): • Structure: Two adjacent cysteine residues • Function: Mainly attract monocytes, eosinophils, and T-cells • Example: MCP-1 (Monocyte Chemoattractant Protein-1), Eotaxin, MIP-1 alpha C Chemokines (Gamma chemokines): • Structure: One cysteine residue at the N-terminus, lacking the second cysteine • Function: Attract lymphocytes • Example: Lymphotactin CX3C Chemokines: • Structure: Three amino acids between the two cysteine residues • Function: Mainly involved in lymphocyte and monocyte recruitment, especially in chronic inflammation • Example: Fractalkine (CX3CL1), which has both chemotactic and adhesive properties

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes are responsible for generating ‘oxygen burst’ within neutrophils for killing intracellular bacteria?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The enzyme responsible for generating the oxygen burst in neutrophils is NADPH oxidase. This enzyme is responsible for the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS), such as superoxide anion (O2-) from oxygen, which is used to kill intracellular bacteria during phagocytosis Other options: Superoxide dismutase (A): Converts superoxide anions (O2-) into hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), but is not directly responsible for the oxygen burst Glutathione peroxidase (B): Detoxifies hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) to water (H2O) using glutathione, helping to protect the cells from oxidative damage Catalase (D): Breaks down hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) into water and oxygen, protecting cells from oxidative damage

questions.text: Which of the following is an Opsonin?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) C3b C3b is a key opsonin in the immune response. It binds to the surface of pathogens and facilitates their recognition and engulfment by phagocytes through receptors such as CR1 Important opsonin’s: C3b, C4b, C5b, Fc portion of IgG Other options: C3a: A complement fragment that is involved in inflammation and acts as a chemoattractant but is not an opsonin C5a: Another complement fragment involved in inflammation and chemotaxis, but not an opsonin LTC4: A leukotriene involved in the inflammatory response, particularly in bronchoconstriction and increasing vascular permeability, but it is not an opsonin

questions.text: Which Collagen is typical of basement membrane?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Type IV

questions.text: All of the following are Intermediate filament except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cadherins are cell adhesion molecules, not intermediate filaments. They are involved in cell-cell adhesion, not in providing structural support within the cytoplasm Intermediate filaments: Intermediate filaments are one of the three major types of cytoskeletal filaments, alongside microfilaments and microtubules. They are composed of various fibrous proteins and are responsible for maintaining cell shape, providing mechanical strength, and anchoring organelles Examples of intermediate filaments: • Keratin • Vimentin • Lamin • Desmin • GFAP • Neurofilaments

questions.text: Heritable changes in gene expression not caused by alterations in DNA sequence refers to?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A- Genetics is the study of genes, genetic variation, and heredity in living organism Option C- A gene mutation is a permanent alteration in the DNA sequence Option D- DNA sequence that can change its position within a genome, sometimes creating or reversing mutations and altering the cell’s genetic identity and genome size. Transposition often results in duplication of the same genetic material

questions.text: Epigenetic factors refers to?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Epigenetic factors include- • Histone methylation • Histone phosphorylation • Histone acetylation • DNA methylation • Chromatin organising factors

questions.text: Collagen present in cornea?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) MOST COMMON IN CORNEA IS TYPE I MOST COMMON IN VITREOUS IS TYPE II

questions.text: Gene silencing RNA-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Noncoding RNAs are encoded by genes that are transcribed but not translated. Although many distinct families of noncoding RNAs exist, we will only discuss two examples here: small RNA molecules called microRNAs, and long noncoding RNAs >200 nucleotides in length. Post transcriptional silencing of gene expression by miRNA is a fundamental and well-conserved mechanism of gene regulation present in all eukaryotes (plants and animals). Option A- ribosomal RNA Option B- transfer RNA

choices.text: Cytokeratin is the marker of muscle cells
Vimentin is used to stain fibroblasts
Desmin can be used as a marker for muscle cells

questions.text: Which of the following statement is not true?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cytokeratin is a marker for epithelial cells Option B- Vimentin is a marker for mesenchymal cells and tumors arising from them Option C- stains axons of neurofilaments Option D- stains muscle cells and tumors arising from them

questions.text: Which of the following is a negative acute phase reactant?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Negative acute-phase proteins The liver responds by producing a large number of APRs. At the same time, the production of a number of other proteins is reduced; these are therefore referred to as “negative” APPs. Negative APPs are albumin, transferrin, transthyretin, transcortin, and retinol-binding protein. Positive acute-phase proteins Positive APPs are CRP, D-dimer protein, mannose-binding protein, alpha 1 antitrpysin, alpha 1 antichymotrypsin, alpha 2 macroglobulin, fibrinogen, prothrombin, factor VIII, von-Willebrand factor, plasminogen, complement factors, ferritin, SAP complement, SAA, ceruloplasmin (Cp), and haptoglobin (Hp). Positive APPs serve different physiological functions for the immune system. Some act to destroy or inhibit growth of microbes, e.g., CAA and Hp. Others give negative feedback on the inflammatory response, e.g., serpins, alpha 2 macroglobulin and coagulation factors affect coagulation. Positive APPs are produced during the APR associated with anorexia and changed metabolism.

questions.text: Th 1 cells produce?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Primary granules of neutrophil have?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Proteinase 3 Primary granules contain enzymes critical for the destruction of pathogens and are involved in the early stages of phagocytosis Contents: Myeloperoxidase, elastase, proteinase 3, lysozyme, defensins, acid hydrolases Secondary granules contain antimicrobial proteins that help with tissue infiltration, modulation of the immune response, and antimicrobial activity Contents: Lactoferrin, lysozyme, collagenase, alkaline phosphatase, gelatinase

questions.text: Major basic protein is found in?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Larger granules of eosinophils contain- Major basic protein; Acid hydrolases; Peroxidase; Phospholipase; Cathepsin; Eosinophil cationic protein; Eosinophil-derived neurotoxin

questions.text: The following are labile cells except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hepatocytes Labile cells: Continuously divide throughout life. Examples include bone marrow, intestinal epithelium, and skin epithelium Stable cells: Do not normally divide but can regenerate if needed (e.g., hepatocytes, renal tubular cells, fibroblasts) Permanent cells: Do not proliferate after birth (e.g., neurons, cardiac muscle cells, and skeletal muscle cells)

questions.text: Liver biopsy in chronic RHF shows?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Congestion of the hepatic and portal vessels may produce pathologic changes in the liver, the spleen, and the GI tract. The liver is usually increased in size and weight (congestive hepatomegaly) due to prominent passive congestion, greatest around the central veins. Grossly, this is reflected as congested red-brown pericentral zones, with relatively normal-colored tan periportal regions, producing the characteristic “nutmeg liver” appearance

questions.text: Heart failure cells are:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Congested tissues take on a dusky reddish- blue color (cyanosis) due to red cell stasis and the presence of deoxygenated hemoglobin. Microscopically, acute pulmonary congestion exhibits engorged alveolar capillaries, alveolar septal edema, and focal intraalveolar hemorrhage. In chronic pulmonary con gestion, which is often caused by congestive heart failure, the septa are thickened and fibrotic, and the alve oli often contain numerous hemosiderin-laden macrophages called heart failure cells

questions.text: Hypercoagulability due to defective factor V gene is called:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Approximately 2% to 15% of Caucasians carry a singlenucleotide mutation in factor V that is called the factor V Leiden, after the city in The Netherlands where it was discovered.

questions.text: Which of the following glycosaminoglycans is not produced in the golgi apparatus?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 4 distinct families of GAGs Heparan Sulphate Chondroitin/Dermatan Sulphate Keratan Sulphate Hyaluronan (HA) First three synthesized and assembled in the Golgi apparatus and RER as proteoglycans HA is produced at the plasma membrane by enzymes and is not linked to a protein backbone

questions.text: Healing tissue has which type of collagen
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A- scar tissue Option D- basement membrane Initially healing tissue has predominant type III collagen; as the wound matures, type III collagen begins to decrease and type I collagen begins to increase till a ratio between former : later = 1:4 is reached

questions.text: In mediating acute phase response of inflammation which of the following does not play a major role?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Acute-phase proteins are plasma proteins, mostly synthesized in the liver, whose plasma concentrations may increase several hundredfold as part of the response to inflammatory stimuli. Three of the bestknown of these proteins are Creactive protein (CRP), fibrinogen, and serum amyloid A (SAA) protein. Synthesis of these molecules in hepatocytes is stimulated by cytokines, especially IL6 (for CRP and fibrinogen) and IL1 or TNF (for SAA).

questions.text: The following histopathological picture is from a patient with cough, night sweats and a cheesy white focus in left upper lobe of lung. The principle cell involved here is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The photograph shows central necrosis with lymphocytes, epithelioid histiocytes and Langhan’s type of giant cell. Principle cell of a granuloma is an epithelioid histiocyte formed by activation of macrophages.

questions.text: Eosinophillia is found in?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Refer to answer above Parasitic infections produce eosinophilia

questions.text: Leukocyte migration through endothelium is induced by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Rolling- P and E selectins on endothelial cells, L selectins and Sialyl lewis X on leucocytes Adhesion- VCAM and ICAM on endothelial cells, beta 1 and 2 integrins on leucocytes Transmigration- CD 31/PECAM on both endothelial cells and leucocytes

questions.text: Which of the following is the chief mediator associated with resetting the hypothalamic temperature set point at a higher level, resulting in fever?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) PGE2 Prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) is the primary prostaglandin responsible for inducing fever as part of the acute phase response during inflammation and it is also hyperalgesic, makes the skin hypersensitive to painful stimuli Other options: PGF2? is involved in smooth muscle contraction (including in the uterus and the eye) and vasoconstriction PGE1 is involved in vasodilation, smooth muscle relaxation, and has anti-platelet effects PGI2 (Prostacyclin) is a vasodilator and inhibitor of platelet aggregation, playing a protective role in cardiovascular health by preventing clot formation and promoting blood flow, particularly in the arteries and lungs. It counteracts the effects of thromboxane A2, which promotes clotting and vasoconstriction

questions.text: Pain during inflammation is mediated by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Bradykinin is a plasma derived mediator which causes vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, drop in blood pressure and mediates pain response. Single best answer here is bradykinin.

questions.text: The following is not a chemoattractant in acute inflammation:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Kinins mediate increased vascular permeability, vasodilation and pain in inflammation

questions.text: Stellate Granuloma are seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Naked granuloma (lack of lymphocytic collar around the granuloma) is seen in Sarcoidosis [non-caseating granuloma]

questions.text: A 9 years old boy is admitted with acute abdominal pain localized in the right illac fossa. He is pyrexia with localized peritonism in RIF. The causative cell involved here:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Acute inflammation - Neutrophils predominant

choices.text: Main function is in tissue repair

questions.text: True statement about alternative macrophage activation (PGI type)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D, E)

questions.text: The principle cell in granuloma
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Macrophage recruitment and activation forms an epithelioid histiocyte which when fuse can form giant cells

questions.text: Durck granuloma is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: Hallmark of chronic inflammation:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Three features of chronic inflammation include- tissue destruction, mononuclear cell infiltrate and attempts at healing in the form of angiogenesis and repair

questions.text: Granulomatous inflammation seen in A/E:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) AIDS due to HIV (viral infection) does not on its own present with granulomas. Other causes may present with them.

questions.text: Necrotizing epitheloid cell granulomas are seen in all, except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Infectious causes of granulomas are many and not all have necrosis (caseous or otherwise)

questions.text: Cell involved in the immediate phase of wound healing:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Fibrin clot formation is the earliest event of wound healing

questions.text: Scar contraction is caused by?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Scar contraction is mainly driven by myofibroblasts, which contract the wound by generating mechanical force. This contraction helps to reduce the size of the wound and bring the wound edges closer together. The process is regulated by factors like TGF-β and the presence of collagen and actin filaments

questions.text: In a sutured incised wound, re-epithelialization is complete by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 5 days In a sutured incised wound, re-epithelialization is typically complete by 5 days, as epithelial cells migrate to cover the wound. Granulation tissue forms rapidly, with maximum granulation tissue and collagen formation occurring at the margins of the wound

choices.text: Aberration of anatomy of vessel wall
Irreversible changes in functional state of vessel wall
Increased expression of adhesion molecules for leukocyte recruitment

questions.text: Endothelium activation refers to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) In the cellular events of inflammation, expression of adhesion molecules on both leucocytes and endothelial cells for facilitating rolling, adhesion and transmigration is called activation

questions.text: Weibel-palade bodies are present in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Weibel palade bodies are seen in endothelial cells and contain tPA, angiopoietin-2, osteoprotegerin, and various cytokines, as well as P-selectin, a transmembrane protein with a large lumenal domain and short cytoplasmic tail along with von willebrand factor

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of cell cycle phase and cyclin/CDK is incorrectly matched?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) S phase- cyclin A/CDK 6 Cyclin A associates with CDK-2, not CDK-6 during the S phase Other options: G1S checkpoint - Cyclin D/CDK-6: Cyclin D binds to CDK-4 and CDK-6 at the G1 phase to help drive the cell cycle through the G1/S transition G1S checkpoint - Cyclin D/CDK-4: Cyclin D partners with CDK-4 (and CDK-6) to phosphorylate the retinoblastoma protein (Rb), promoting progression from G1 to S phase G2M checkpoint - Cyclin B/CDK-1: Cyclin B binds to CDK-1 at the G2/M checkpoint, promoting the transition from G2 to M phase and initiating mitosis

questions.text: Major cytokine involved in fibrosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Transforming growth factor beta (TGF-beta) is a central mediator of fibrogenesis. TGF-beta is upregulated and activated in fibrotic diseases and modulates fibroblast phenotype and function, inducing myofibroblast transdifferentiation while promoting matrix preservation

questions.text: Most abundant collagen in the body?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: A 60-years-old man suddenly becomes completely blind in one eye, and angiography demonstrates occlusion of the central retinal artery. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the occlusion?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Atheroma or embolism The point of this question is that sometimes the obvious explanation is the correct one. Occlusion of the central retinal artery rapidly causes irreversible blindness with loss of inner retinal layers. (The photoreceptor rod and cone cells are maintained by the pigment epithelium). The site of occlusion is typically just posterior to the cribriform plate. A garden-variety atheroma or embolism is over-whelming the most common cause of central retinal artery occlusion.

questions.text: A patient complains to her physician that the feels lightheades and has even fainted during defecations. This is most probably an example of syncope due to which of the following mechanism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) Valsalva mechanism Syncope has abroad differential diagnosis, since fainting can be produced by a wide variety of mechanisms. All of the mechanisms listed in the answers can produce syncope, but only the Valsalva mechanism (in which high intra-abdominal pressures trigger a reflex fall in cardiac output) is specifically associated with defecation. This mechanism can also produce fainting during weight-lifting and with the use of wind instruments.

questions.text: A 65-years old man comes to the emergency department because of chest pain and shortness of breath. An electrocardiogram shows ST elevations and new Q waves. Despite appropriate care, the patient dies. The family agrees to an autopsy, which shows extensive atherosclerotic disease. The finding of which of the following features in an atherosclerotic plaque indicates that it has become a complicated lesion?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Lines of Zahn Complicated lesions indicate advanced atherosclerotic disease. They arise in the atherosclerotic plaques and render them more susceptible to sudden occlusion and acute infarction of hte supplied tissues. Commonly, the plaque ulcerates or ruptures, and the exposed surfaces, being highly thrombogenic, precipitate thrombus formation. Thrombi are typified by the lens of Zahn, alternating layers of platelets and fibrin (the pale lines), and layers of blood (the dark lines). Beyond thrombus formation, other features of a complicated plaque include hemorrhage into the lesion itself, and micro embolism by cholesterol crystals or calcified debris. Furthermore, the weakened media underlying the plaque may develop an aneurysmal dilatation. In general, the clinical significance of atherosclerosis is related to the consequence of complicated lesions. The incorrect options all include features of atheromatous plaques but do not indicated complicated lesions.

questions.text: Which of the following substances is produced by the action of lipoxygenase on arachidonic acid, is a potent chemotactic factor for neutrophils, and causes aggregation and adhesion of leukocytes?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Leukotriene B4 Products of arachidonic acid (AA) metabolism are involved extensively in inflammation. In this pathway, AA is broken down into leukotrienes (vasoconstrictors) and prostaglandins vasodilators). AA is a polyunsaturated fatty acid that is normally found esterified in plasma membrane phospholipids. It is released by the activation of phospholipases, such as phospholipase A2. Cyclooxygenase transforms AA into the prostaglandin endoperoxide PGG2, which is then converted into PGH2and subsequently into three products: thromboxane A2 (TxA2), prostacyclin (PGI2), and the more stable prostaglandins PGE2, PGF2, and PGD2. Thromboxane, found in platelets, is a potent platelet aggregator and blood vessel constrictor. LTB4, IL-8, C5a are chemotactic agents

questions.text: A woman who was in a major motor vehicle accident has a femoral fracture. She develops shortness of breath, confusion, and thrombocytopenia shortly after arriving at the emergency room. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Fat embolism syndrome Embolisms occur when blood clots or other materials (air, amniotic fluid, or fat and bone marrow) are carried by the blood to distant sites in the body. The most common is embolism of a deep venous thrombosis to the pulmonary artery, termed a pulmonary embolism. This patient has had a recent major bone fracture, which predisposes her to fat and bone marrow embolism throughout the body. Patients who become symptomatic have fat embolism syndrome, which typically results in pulmonary problems, neurologic symptoms, anemia, and thrombocytopenia. Gurd's criteria is used for diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome
